content.question: A uniform disk spins about an axis that passes through the center of the disk and is perpendicular to the plane of the disk, as shown in Figure 1. The disk has an initial angular velocity of <math alttext="omega sub d" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>ω</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and uniformly accelerates to rest over time. The angular velocity of the disk as a function of time is shown in Figure 2. A student must determine the angular displacement of a point on the edge of the disk from <math alttext="t equals 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> to the instant in time the disk comes to rest if the point’s initial velocity is changed to <math alttext="2 omega sub d" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn><msub><mrow><mi>ω</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> but its angular acceleration is the same as shown in Figure 2. How can the graph in Figure 2 be changed before the student can determine the angular displacement? Justify your selection.
